titleStmt.title: Finite-time Convergence Adaptive Fuzzy Control for Dual-Arm Robot with Unknown Kinematics and Dynamics

analytic.title: Finite-time Convergence Adaptive Fuzzy Control for Dual-Arm Robot with Unknown Kinematics and Dynamics

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TFUZZ.2018.2864940, IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Due to strongly coupled nonlinearities of or the grasped dual-arm robot and the internal forces generated by grasped objects, the dual-arm robot control with uncertain kinematics and dynamics becomes a challenging problem. In this paper, an adaptive fuzzy control scheme is developed for a dual arm robot, where an approximate Jacobian matrix (AJM) was applied to address the uncertain kinematic control, while decentralized fuzzy logic controller (FLC) was constructed to compensate for uncertain dynamics of the robotic arms and the manipulated object. Also, a novel finite-time convergence parameter adaptation (FCPA) technique was developed for the estimation of kinematic parameters and fuzzy logic weights, such that the estimation was guaranteed to converge to small neighborhoods around their ideal values in a finite time. Moreover, a partial persistent excitation (PPE) property of Gaussian membership based fuzzy basis function (GFBF) was established to relax the conventional persistent excitation (PE) condition. This enables the designer to re-use these learned weight values next time without relearning. Extensive simulation studies have been carried out based on a dual-arm robot to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: In recent decades, there has been a pronounced tendency to focus the studies of coordinated dual-arm robots in robotics and automation communities [1]- [5]. With a bimanual cooperation, the dual-arm robots can accomplish complex tasks, such as cooperative load transporting and coordinate manipulation. But difficulties of the controller designs are also increased significantly since an additional arm not only leads to complicated structure and mechanism, but also adds strong coupled nonlinearities as well as the internal forces generated by the grasped object. To address these problems, coordinate control of dual arm robots has been widely investigated [6]- [10]. Early work of the dual-arm coordinate position tracking control was presented in [1], [2]. A decentralized adaptive control algorithm was proposed for multiple redundant cooperative manipulators to address the position tracking and internal forces regulation in [6]. In [8], the coordination problem of redundant robot systems was addressed by using the dual neural network with a multicriteria to minimize the energy cost. In [11], an adaptive neural control for the humanoid robot was presented to deal with unknown output nonlinearities by employing a smooth adaptive inverse technique.

It is worth mentioning that, many existing dual-arm robot coordinated control schemes were developed under the assumption that the robot kinematics are fully known. However, in realistic operational scenarios, kinematic uncertainties are widely existed. For example, when a dual arm robot equips with replaceable tools or grasps an unknown object, the system parameters may be changed and lead to unknown kinematic parameters. Recently, the robot tracking control with uncertain kinematics for single-arm robots has been reported [12]- [16]. An adaptive set-point control scheme of robots with uncertain kinematics and gravitational force was proposed in [14], where the exact knowledge of kinematics and Jacobian matrix was not required. This scheme has been extended to the robot tracking control [15], without using knowledge of robotic kinematics, dynamics and actuator model. A neural network controller combining with the (approximate Jacobian matrix) AJM scheme was also presented to deal with the robot tracking in the absence of kinematics and dynamics [12]. The uncertain kinematics control of a single arm robot was well addressed in the above-mentioned works, however, few literature has investigated the control of the dual-arm robot where accurate kinematic parameters are unavailable. Without precise kinematic information, the task space position can not be accurately converted to joint inputs, and therefore the control performance of the dual-arm robot may be greatly limited.

On the other hand, dynamic uncertainties of the dual-arm robot widely exists as well, let alone various unknown factors of the operating environment and the objects under manipulation. These uncertainties may cause degeneration of the control performance or even incur instable system states. To deal with this problem, especially the unstructured model uncertainties, model free control design approaches have been extensively studied [17]- [24]. It is worth mentioning that, among these control approaches, fuzzy logic systems was characterized as a powerful approximator by using linguistic knowledge representations and fuzzy rules, and has been wildly used to deal with uncertainties [25]- [31]. To address the strictfeedback control of single-input-single-output (SISO) systems, a FLS was constructed for the compensation of uncertain nonlinearities in [25]. To compensate for the unknown system dynamics of a class of nonlinear systems, a backstepping based adaptive controller was developed by utilizing the universal approximation ability of FLS [32]. In [33], to enhance the control performance of a humanoid robot in the presence of unknown actuator backlash and uncertain dynamics, a decentralized controller was designed by using the adaptive FLS and a smooth backlash inverse. In the above mentioned works, however, only ultimate boundedness of the weights estimation error can be guaranteed and the convergence of the weights was not analysed. The FLS is required to online adjust the learned weights to transform the expert linguistic knowledge into adaptive learning ability of the control system. Without convergence, the weight values need to re-learn every time when the FLS runs again even if repeating the same task. It would be more desirable to guarantee fast and accurate convergence of estimated parameters to improve the control performance [34].

In this paper, we develop a dual arm robot control scheme by using the AJM technique and the adaptive FLS, such that the robot can be well controlled in the absence of robot dynamics and kinematics. The proposed control scheme can guarantee the convergence of the tracking errors in a finitetime, in addition to the parameter estimation. It has been reported that the estimation performance can be improved if the adaptation law contains the information of the estimation errors [35]. An adaptive estimation technique was proposed in [36], where the parameter estimation errors were used to ensure the convergence of the estimated parameters. In [37], an optimal control strategy was applied in a nonlinear system by using the dynamic programming algorithm to ensure the finite-time convergence. Inspired by the concept of 'direct' parameters estimation [35]- [38], in this paper, a finite-time adaptive estimation algorithm is developed by introducing a leakage term driven by parameter estimation errors, such that the estimated kinematic parameters can converge to small neighborhoods of their optimal values in finite time.

It should be noted that persistent excitation (PE) condition is important to guarantee the convergence of estimated parameters [34]. However, for conventional FLS, the requirement of the PE condition is restricted and not easy to be satisfied. In [39], a partial persistent excitation (PPE) is proposed to relax the PE condition of the neural network control, which proved that the PE condition of certain regression subvectors of radical basis functions along with a recurrent trajectory (e.g., periodic and periodic-like orbits) could be rigorously guaranteed [39]. Inspired by this work, in this paper, the PPE condition of FLS is investigated to replace the conventionally used PE condition. Based on the PPE condition, an adaptive weights updating scheme is further developed by introducing an auxiliary framework to express the weights errors. Under the PPE condition, the finite-time convergence of partial FLS weight estimated and accurate approximation of unknown dynamics are guaranteed.
The main contributions of the proposed control scheme could be summarized as follows:

• Construction of an adaptive fuzzy logic control scheme for the coordinated robot arms with neither a priori knowledge of system dynamics nor information of the kinematic parameters. • Design a novel parameters adaptation framework by applying a set of auxiliary filtered matrices, such that the parameter estimation errors could be appropriately expressed without using the robot joint accelerations. • Relaxing the PE condition by introducing the concepts of the PPE and SLA of the FLS, such that the weights could converge to their optimal values when tracks a periodic trajectory.

div.head: II. MODELLING PROCEDURE OF THE ROBOT AND PRELIMILARIES A. Kinematics Modeling of the Dual-arm Robot
div.p: As shown in Fig. 1, the dual arm robot is commanded to grasp a common object to follow a reference trajectory. Assume that the end-effector of each arm grasps the object rigidly so that no relative motion occurs between the endeffectors and the object. Then, the object's position and orientation vector can be calculated by the joint variable of each arm as below:
div.formula: x = f kinei (q i ), i = 1, 2(1)
div.p: where x ∈ R N0 is the position of the object, N 0 is the object's degree of freedom (DOF), q i denotes the joint angle of the ith arm. The subscript "i" denotes the "left" and "right" robotic arm, respectively. Differentiate (1) with respect to time yields
div.formula: ẋ = J i (q i , φ i ) qi(2)
div.p: where φ i ∈ R hi denotes the kinematic parameters of the ith arm, and h i denotes the number of the D-H parameters. J i (q i , φ i ) ∈ R No×Ni is the Jacobian matrix which satisfies the following property. Property 1: [12] The Jacobian matrix J i (q i , φ i ) can be formulated with a linearly parametrized form as
div.formula: J i (q i , φ i )ξ i = R i (q i , ξ i )φ i(3)
div.p: where R i (q i , ξ i ) ∈ R No×hi is the regressor matrix of kinematics with respect to q i and ξ i , ξ i is a known vector. Without loss of generality, we assume that φ i is bounded by known vectors φ i and φ i , as φ i ≥ φ i ≥ φ i , where φ i and φ i denote the lower and upper bounds of φ i , respectively.

From Property 1, we can derive that J i (q i , φ i )ξ i = J i (q i , φi )ξ i + J i (q i , φi )ξ i , where φ i = φi + φi , φi is the estimated kinematic parameters and φi is the estimation error. This property is useful in the identification of the kinematic parameters.

div.head: B. Dynamics Modeling of Dual-arm Robot
div.p: The dynamic model of the ith robotic arm is given by Lagrangian method as follows:
div.formula: H i (q i )q i + D i (q i , qi ) qi + G i (q i ) = τ i + J T ei (q i )F ei(4)
div.p: where
div.formula: H i (q i ) ∈ R Ni×Ni , D i (q i , qi ) ∈ R Ni×Ni , G i (q i ) ∈ R Ni
div.p: are the inertial matrix, Coriolis matrix and gravity term, respectively. N i denotes the DOF of ith robotic arm. J T ei (q i ) is the Jacobian matrix of ith robotic arm, while τ i ∈ R Ni is the joint torque, F ei ∈ R N0 is the external force exerted at the ith end-effector. The dynamics of the object can be described as follows
div.formula: H o (x)ẍ + D o (x, ẋ) ẋ + G o (x) = F o(5)
div.p: where H o (x) ∈ R N0×N0 denotes the inertial matrix of the object; D o (x, ẋ) ∈ R N0×N0 is the Coriolis and centrifugal matrix; G o (x) ∈ R N0×N0 is the object's gravity term, while F o ∈ R N0 denotes the result force exerted on the object. As shown from Fig. 1, the force F o can be represented by two force vectors as follows
div.formula: F o = -F oe1 -F oe2(6)
div.p: where F oei ∈ R N0 is the interaction force applied by the object on the ith end-effector. The relationship between F oei and F ei is described as
div.formula: F oei = J T oei (x)F ei(7)
div.p: where J oei (x) ∈ R N0×N0 is the manipulated Jacobian matrix from the ith manipulator's end-effector to the mass center of the object. The force F oei can be decomposed to an external force and an internal force, such that
div.formula: F oei = f i + f oi(8)
div.p: where the external forces f oi only contribute to the motion of the object, while the internal forces
div.formula: f i satisfy f 1 + f 2 = 0 [n] .
div.p: The combination of equations ( 5), ( 6) and ( 8) yields
div.formula: H o (x)ẍ + D o (x, ẋ) ẋ + G o (x) = -f o1 -f o2(9)
div.p: The external force f oi could be represented as below [33],
div.formula: f oi = -C i (t) H o (x)ẍ + D o (x, ẋ) ẋ + G o (x)(10)
div.p: where C i (t) is a positive definite N 0 × N 0 diagonal matrix denoting the object load distribution onto the ith robotic arm, with C 1 (t) + C 2 (t) = I N0 , I N0 ∈ R N0×N0 is an identity matrix. Substituting ( 9) and ( 10) into (8) we have
div.formula: f i = F oei -C i (t)(f o1 + f o2 )(11)
div.p: Let us combine (4), ( 5), ( 6), ( 8), (11) and the kinematic equations ( 1) -( 2), the dynamics of the ith robotic arm could be reformulated as below
div.formula: τ i = H i (q i )q i + D i (q i , qi ) qi + G i (q i ) -J T i (q i , φ i )f i (12) where H i = H i +C i H o , H o = J T i M o J i , D i = D i +C i (H D + D o ), D o = J T i D o J i , H D = J T i H o Ji , G i = G i +C i G o , G o = J T i G o , J ei = J oei J i .
div.p: To facilitate the analysis, a number of useful properties and assumptions are given as below Property 2: [7] The matrix 2D i (q i , qi ) -[ Ḣi (q i ) -Ċi (t)H o (q i , qi )] is skew-symmetric and satisfies that:
div.formula: ∂ T 2D i (q i , qi ) -Ḣi (q i ) -Ċi (t)H o (q i , qi ) ∂ = 0, ∀∂ Property 3: [7]
div.p: The term Ċi (t)H 0 (q i ) is uniformly continuous and bounded by a known constant as,
where is a positive constant.
Assumption 1: The Jacobian matrices of the robotic arms are of full rank during the operation.

Assumption 2: The robot grasp the object tightly such that no relative motion or rotation occurs between the object and grasper. In addition, the rigid object would not be deformed by the applied forces.
Assumption 3: The reference task space trajectory x d and its time derivative ẋd are continuous and bounded.

C. Preliminaries 1) Fuzzy logic system (FLS): FLS has been widely applied in the control of nonlinear systems by its powerful ability to approximate complex systems and no requirement of a priori experience of system dynamics. Considering the unknown nonlinear function F (z) ∈ R m , and the measurable scalar input z ∈ R n , with n and m being the dimensions of the input and output, respectively, we employ a multi-input-multioutput (MIMO) FLS to approximated an unknown nonlinear system F (z) with the following steps [40] i) Fuzzification: Fuzzification maps a real scalar input z into fuzzy linguistic terms by using membership functions. ii) Fuzzy IF-THEN rules: The Fuzzy IF-THEN rules are adopted to relate an input set to an output set with the Mamdani min-implication as below Rule l,
div.formula: (l = 1, 2, • • • , L): If z 1 is A l 1 , z 2 is A l 2 , • • • , z n is A l n , then y 1 is B l 1 , y 2 is B l 2 , • • • , y m is B l m , where z = [z 1 , • • • , z n ] ∈ R n and y = [y 1 , • • • , y m ] ∈ R m are the
div.p: premise variables with respect to the input and output, A l i and B l j are fuzzy sets, i = 1, • • • , n, j = 1, • • • , m, and L is the number of the rules. iii) Fuzzy inference engine and defuzzification: Combining the singleton fuzzifier, sum-product inference, and center-average defuzzifier, the defuzzification can be performed as,
div.formula: y j (z) = L l=1 Φ l j n i=1 µ A l i (z i ) L l=1 n i=1 µ A l i (z i )(13)
div.p: where
div.formula: µ A l i (z i ) is the membership function of linguistic variable A l i (z i ), Φ l j =max yj (z)∈R {µ B l j (Φ l )} is the point at which µ B l j (Φ l j ) achieves its maximum value. Let p l (z) = n i=1 µ A l i (zi) L l=1 n i=1 µ A l i (zi) , P (z) = [p 1 (z), p 2 (z), • • • , p L (z)] T ∈ R L , W j = [Φ 1 j , Φ 2 j , • • • , Φ L j ] T ∈ R L , W = [W 1 , W 2 , • • • , W m ] ∈ R L×m .
div.p: Then, the fuzzy logic systems can be rewritten as follows:
div.formula: y(z) = W T P (z)(14)
div.p: Lemma 1: [31] Let f j (z) ∈ R be a continuous function defined on a compact set Ω j , then for any given constant j , there exists a FLS such that
div.formula: sup fj (z)∈Ωj |f j (z) -y j (z)| ≤ j(15)
div.p: where
div.formula: y j = W T j P (z). In terms of Lemma 1, F (z) = [f 1 (z), f 2 (z), • • • , f m (z)] ∈ R m can be formulated as F (z) = W T P (z) + ε (16
div.p: where W ∈ R L×m is the optimal weight matrix, P ∈ R L is the fuzzy basis vector, ε ∈ R m is the approximation error, and L is the number of fuzzy rules.

2) Spatially localized approximation (SLA) [41]: The SLA means that for any bounded trajectory z which remains in a compact set Ω, the unknown function f (z) can be approximated by a limited number of fuzzy rules in a local region (close to the trajectory z) as,
div.formula: f (z) = W * T ξ P ξ (z) + ε ξ (z)(17)
div.p: where
div.formula: P ξ (z) = [p 1 ξ (z), • • • , p L ξ (z)] T ∈ R L ξ denotes a subvector of P , with L ξ < L, |p lξ | > ς with ς being a small positive constant, W * ξ = [W * T j1 , • • • , W * T jξ ]
div.p: T represents the corresponding weight matrix, and ε ξ is the construction error which satisfies ||ε ξ (z) -ε(z)|| ≤ σ, with σ being a small value.
3) Partial PE condition: In the parameter estimation, the PE condition is important to ensure the convergence of estimated parameters. The definition of PE condition could be described as below.

Definition 1: [36] A vector or matrix P (t) is called persistently excited if there exist two constant T > 0 and > 0, such that t+T t P T (r)P (r) dr ≥ I, ∀t ≥ 0 Note that for FLS, the PE condition is relatively strict and not easy to be satisfied. To relax the PE condition, we introduce a partial PE condition for the FLS with the Gaussian membership function, which is established by the following theorem.

Theorem 1: Consider a periodic trajectory Z(t), which is continuous on a compact set Ω, and Ż(t) is bounded. For an FLS W T P (Z) with P (Z) chosen to be Gaussian fuzzy membership functions, and the centers placed on a regular lattice (large enough to cover the compact set Ω), the regressor subvector P ξ (Z(t)) could satisfy the PE condition.

Proof: See the Appendix I. Remark 1: In the previous studies [39], [41], [42], the SLA of the radical basis function based neural network (RBFNN) was well established, such that the accurate approximation can be achieved by a limited number of neural nodes. This property has been widely employed in the identification of system dynamics such as robotic manipulators [39], unmanned surface vessels [42], faults detection system [43], etc. Inspired by the above discussion, in this paper, we investigate the partial PE property of the FLS. We have proved that the partial PE condition of FLS holds if the inputs trajectory is periodic. Which means that the partial PE condition of FLS could be more easy to satisfy.

Remark 2: Theorem 1 shows that for the GFBFs whose centers are close to the periodic trajectory, the PE condition could be relaxed to partial PE condition, and hence the convergence of the estimated weights is more easy to satisfy. On the other hand, for the GFBFs whose centers are far away from the tracking trajectory, the weights are only slightly updated.

div.head: A. Control Design for the Closed-Loop Robot System
div.p: Step 1: Define the tracking error as e x = x(t) -x d (t). Taking its differentiation with respect to time, we have
div.formula: ėx = ẋ(t) -ẋd (t) = J i (q i , φ i ) qi -ẋd(18)
div.p: where ẋ = J i (q i , φ i ) qi holds according to (2). Then, an auxiliary controller qdi is designed as below:
div.formula: qdi = J + i (q i , φi )( ẋd -K e e x -α fi )(19)
div.p: where J + i (q i , φi ) is the Moore-Penrose inverse of J i (q i , φi ), K e is the control gain, α fi is an auxiliary term defined by α fi = β fi Λ Fi , with β fi being a positive constant, and Λ Fi is a leakage term which will be designed later. The combination of (3) ( 18) and ( 19) yields, ėx = -K e e x + J i (q i , φ i )e qi + R i (q i , qdi ) φi -α fi (20) where e qi = qi -qdi .
Step 2: Substituting equations ( 18) and ( 19) into (12), we have
div.formula: H i (q i ) ėqi + D i (q i , qi )e qi = τ i -H i (q i )q di -D i (q i , qi ) qdi -G i (q i ) + J i (q i , φ i )f i(21)
F i (z i ) = H i (q i )q di + D i (q i , qi ) qdi + G i (q i )(22)
div.p: where
div.formula: z i = [q T di , qT di , q T i , qT i ] T . Since H i (q i ), D i (q i , qi
div.p: ) and G i (q i ) are not available, we use an FLS to approximate (22) as
div.formula: F i (z i ) = W T Fi P Fi + ε Fi (23
div.p: where W Fi ∈ R σ F i ×Ni is the optimal FLS weight matrix, and
div.formula: P Fi (z i ) = [P Fi 1 (z i ), P Fi 2 (z i ), • • • , P Fiσ F i (z i )] T ∈ R σ F i
div.p: is the fuzzy basis vector, σ Fi is the number of fuzzy rules, and ε Fi ∈ R Ni is the construction error.
Then, the controller τ i can be designed as follows
div.formula: τ i = Fi (e qi )-K i e qi -J T i (q i , φi )(e x -K fi Λ fi +f di )+Υ i (e qi ) (24) where K i is the selected control gain, Fi (z i ) = Ŵ T Fi P Fi (z i ), and ŴFi ∈ R σ F i ×Ni is the estimation of W Fi , f di is the desired internal force. The robust term Υ i (e qi ) is designed as Υ i (e qi ) = -β i eq i ||eq i ||
div.p: e qi = 0 0 otherwise , and β i is a selected positive constant. And Λ fi is defined as
div.formula: Λ fi = t 0 fi dt, fi = f i -f di .
div.p: The overall control scheme is shown in Fig. 2.
Substituting (23) and ( 24) into ( 21), the closed-loop error dynamics of the dual-arm robot can be rewritten as
div.formula: H i (q i ) ėqi + D i (q i , qi )e qi = -K i e qi -J T i (q i , φi )e x + Υ i (e qi ) + J T i (q i , φ i )f i -J T i (q i , φi )(f di -K fi Λ fi ) + ε Fi + W T Fi S Fi (z i )(25)
div.p: where WFi = ŴFi -W Fi .

div.head: B. Finite-Time Kinematic Parameter Estimation Design
div.p: In this section, we will preform the parameters estimation design of the unknown system parameters.
1) FCPA design of the kinematic parameters: In order to derive the parameter estimation of φi , we define an auxiliary matrix U i ∈ R hi×hi , and two vectors
div.formula: T i ∈ R Ni , P i ∈ R Ni as      Ui = -ζ i U i + R i (q i , qi ) T R i (q i , qi ) U i (0) = 0 Ṫi = -ζ i T i + R i (q i , qi ) T ẋ T i (0) = 0 P i = T i -U i φi(26)
div.p: where ζ i is a positive constant that introduces a forgetting factor for the filter matrix. Which can be designed to make a trade-off of the robustness and the convergence rate.
By integrating on both sides of ( 26) with respect to time, the solution of U i and T i can be derived as
div.formula:        U i (t) = t 0 e -ζi(t-r) R i (q i (r), qi (r)) T R i (q i (r), qi (r))dr T i (t) = t 0 e -ζi(t-r) R i (q i (r), qi (r)) T ẋ(r)dr (27)
div.p: Remark 3: From the analysis in Section II, we have ẋ = R(q i , qi )φ i . Comparing the structure between T i and U i in (27), we can derive that T i = U i φ i . Then, P i can be represented by P i = U i φ i -U i φi = U i φi . In this sense, the term P i contains the information of estimation error of φ i . This is important to improve the estimation performance.
Then, the updating law for φi is designed by using the following projection algorithm,
div.formula: ( φi ) k =                      -λ i R T i (q i , qdi )e x + κ i U T i P i ||P i || + N i k if (φ i ) k ≤ ( φi ) k ≤ (φ i ) k ; or if ( φi ) k = (φ i ) k and (φ i F ) k ≤ 0; or if ( φi ) k = (φ i ) k and (φ i F ) k ≥ 0; 0 otherwise. (28
div.p: ) where λ i and κ i are positive constants to be specified by the designer, (•) k denotes the kth element of the vector (•), N i is a leakage term which will be designed later,
div.formula: φ i F = -R T i (q i , qdi )e x -κ i U T i Pi
div.p: ||Pi|| -N i , and φ i and φ i are the known lower bound and upper bound of the real value of φ i , respectively.
2) FCPA design of the FLS weights: In order to achieve the FT estimation of the FLS weight parameters without using the joint acceleration qi , the following functions have been designed
div.formula: Ξ i (z ci ) = H i e qi Ψ i (z di ) = -Ḣi e qi + D i (q i , qi )e qi -J T i (q i , φ i )f i(29)
div.p: where
div.formula: z ci = [q T i , qT i , qT di ] T , z di = [q T i , qT i , qT di , f T i ] T
div.p: . By combining (22) and (29), and considering that Ξ(z ci ) = H i ėqi + Ḣi e qi , the closed-loop dual-arm robot system (12) can be represented as
div.formula: F i (z i ) + Ξi (z ci ) + Ψ i (z di ) = τ i(30)
div.p: Since Ξ i (z ci ) and Ψ i (z di ) are not available, the following FLS is constructed for Ξ i and Ψ i as
div.formula: Ξ i (z ci ) = W T Ξi P Ξi + ε Ξi Ψ i (z di ) = W T Ψi P Ψi + ε Ψi (31
div.p: where W Ξi ∈ R σΞ×Ni and W Ψi ∈ R σΨ i ×Ni are the optimal weight matrix, P Ξi ∈ R σΞ i and P Ψi ∈ R σΨ i are the fuzzy basis vectors, and ε Ψi and ε Ξi are the construction errors.
Inspired by the work in [36], we introduce a stable linear filter (•) f = 1 bis+1 (•), b i > 0 on both sides of (30) as follows,
div.formula: F if (z i ) + Ξif (z ci ) + Ψ if (z di ) = W T Fi P Fif + W T Ξi ṖΞif + W T Ψi P Ψif + ε Fif + εΞif + ε Ψif = τ if(32)
div.p: where
div.formula: P Fif ∈ R σ F i , P Ξif ∈ R σΞ i , P Ψif ∈ R σΨ i , ε Fif ∈ R Ni , ε Ξif ∈ R Ni , ε Ψif ∈ R Ni and τ if ∈ R Ni
div.p: are the filtered version of P Ξi , P Ψi , P Fi , ε Fi , ε Ξi , ε Ψi and τ i , respectively, and given as follows,
div.formula:          b i ṖFif + P Fif = P Fi b i εFif + ε Fif = ε Fi b i ṖΞif + P Ξif = P Ξi b i ṖΨif + P Ψif = P Ψi b i εΞif + ε Ξif = ε Ξi b i εΨif + ε Ψif = ε Ψi b i τif + τ if = τ i (33)
div.p: where b i is a positive constant, P Fi (0) = 0, ε Fi (0) = 0, P Ξif (0) = 0, P Ψif (0) = 0, ε Ξif (0) = 0, ε Ψif (0) = 0 and τ i (0) = 0. Then, the filtered dynamics can be rewritten as
div.formula: τ if = W T i S i (Z i ) + ε i (34
div.p: where
div.formula: W i = [W T Fi , ψ T i ] T ∈ R σi×Ni , ψ i = [W T Ξi , W T Ψi ] T ∈ R σ Y i ×Ni are the optimal weight matrix of FLS, S i (Z i ) = [P T F if (z i ), P T Yi (c i )] T ∈ R σi , and P Yi (c i ) = [ P T Ξ i -P T Ξ i f bi , P T Ψif ] T ∈ R σ Y i
div.p: is the fuzzy basis function, σ i = σ Fi + σ Yi with σ Yi being the number of fuzzy rules;
div.formula: ε i = ε F if + ε Yi ∈ R Ni , ε Yi = εΞ i -ε Ξ i f bi
div.p: + ε Ψif ∈ R Ψi are the approximation errors. To derive the parameters estimation of W i , we design the auxiliary filter matrices
div.formula: L i ∈ R σ Y i ×σ Y i , Q i ∈ R σ Y i ×Ni and V i ∈ R σ Y i ×Ni as      Li = -δ i L i + S i (z i )S T i (z i ) L i (0) = 0 Qi = -δ i Q i + S i (z i )τ T if Q i (0) = 0 V i = L i Ŵi -Q i (35)
div.p: where δ i is a positive constant. The solution of L i and Q i are derived by integrating on both sides of (35),
div.formula:        L i (t) = t 0 e -δi(t-r) S i (z i (r))S i (z i (r)) T dr Q i (t) = t 0
div.p: e -δi(t-r) S i (z i (r)) T τ i dr (36) From the definition of V i , L i and Q i in (35) and (36), we have
div.formula: V i = L i Ŵi -L i W i + χ i = L i Wi + χ i(37)
div.p: where χ i = -t 0 exp -δ i (t -r) S i (z i (r))ε i (r)dr. Since ε i and the basis function S i (z i ) are bounded, the χ i is also bounded and satisfies that χ i ≤ χi , where χi is the upper bound of χ i . Then, the FLS weight updating law Ẇi is designed as below:
div.formula: Ẇi = -Γ i (M i S Fi (z i )e T qi + γ i L T i V i ||V i || )(38)
div.p: where
div.formula: M i = I σ F i ×σ F i 0 σ Y i ×σ F i
div.p: and γ i is a positive constant.

div.head: C. Stability Analysis
div.p: The stability analysis of the proposed control algorithm is established by the following theorem.

Theorem 2: Consider the dual-arm robot system grasping a common object in (12). Assume that the regressor matrices R i (q i , qi ) and P i (Z i ) satisfy the PE condition. Then, the adaptive control input τ di developed in (24) with the auxiliary controllers qdi in (19), as well as the parameter adaptation law (28) and the FLS weight adaptation law in (38) can guarantee that (i) all the signals in the closed-loop system are uniformly ultimately bounded. (ii) the tracking error e x converges to a residual set around zero. (iii) the estimate error and Wi could converge to a small neighbourhood around zero.
Proof: Consider the following Lyapunov function for the dual-arm robot
div.formula: V i = V i1 + V i2 + V i3(39)
div.p: where
div.formula: V i1 = 1 2 e T x e x + 1 2λ i φT i φi(40)
V i2 = 1 2 e T qi H i e qi + 1 2 β i Λ T fi Λ fi(41)
V i3 = 1 2 tr W T i Γ -1 i Wi(42)
div.p: and φi = φ i -φi , β i is a positive constant. The differentiation of ( 40) with respect to time gives us
div.formula: Vi1 = e T x ėx + 1 λ i φT i φi(43)
div.p: Substituting equation ( 20) and the updating law ( 28) into (43), yields
div.formula: Vi1 = e T x -K e e x + J i (q i , φ i )e qi + R i (q i , qdi ) φi -α fi + 1 λ i φT i φi = -e T
div.p: x K e e x + e T x J i (q i , φi )e qi + e T x J i (q i , φi )e qi -e T x α fi
div.formula: -φT i R T i (q i , qi )e x + κ i U T i P i ||P i || + N i + e T x R i (q i , qdi ) φi(44)
div.p: As mentioned above, P i can be represented by P i = U i φi . Then (44) can be rewritten as
div.formula: Vi1 = -e T x K e e x + e T x J i (q i , φi )e qi -κ i φT i U T i U i φi ||U i φi || -φT i N i -e T x α fi(45)
div.p: Taking the derivative of V i2 with respect to time yields,
div.formula: Vi2 = e T qi H i ėqi + 1 2 e T qi Ḣi e qi + β i Λ T fi fi(46)
div.p: the error dynamics of the closed-loop system (25) into (46), we have
div.formula: = e T qi -K i e qi + Υ i (e qi ) + W T Fi S Fi (z i ) + ε Fi +e T qi -J T i (q i , φi )(e x + f di -K fi Λ fi ) + J T i (q i , φ i )f i + 1 2 e T qi Ḣi e qi -e T qi D i (q i , qi )e qi + β i Λ T fi fi(47)
div.p: In terms of the Properties 2 and 3 of the dual-arm robot, and employing the inequality e T qi 2D i (q i , qi ) -Ḣi (q i ) e qi ≤ i e T qi e qi , (47) can be rewritten as
div.formula: Vi2 ≤ -K i -i e T qi e qi + e T qi W T Fi S Fi (z i ) + e T qi ε Fi -e T qi J T i (q i , φi )e x + e T qi J T i (q i , φ i )f i -β i ||e qi || -e T qi J T i (q i , φi ) f di -K fi Λ fi + β fi Λ T fi fi(48)
div.p: Note that J i (q i , φ i )e qi = ėx +K e e x -R i (q i , qdi ) φi +α fi and J i (q i , φi )e qi = ėx + K e e x -R i (q i , qi ) φi + α fi hold according to (20), then, the combination of ( 45) and (48) yields
div.formula: Vi1 + Vi2 ≤ -e T x K e e x -K i -i e T qi e qi -β i ||e qi || -κ i ||U i φi || -φT i N i + ėx + K e e x + α fi T (f i -f di + K fi Λ fi ) -φi T R T i (q i , qdi )f i + φi T R T i (q i , qi )f di + e T qi W T Fi S Fi (z i ) -φi T R T i (q i , qi )K fi Λ fi + e T qi ε Fi + β fi Λ T fi fi -e T x β fi Λ Fi(49)
div.p: Let us design N i to be
div.formula: N i = R T i (q i , qi )f di -R T i (q i , qdi )f i - R T i (q i , qi )K fi
div.p: Λ fi and substitute it into (49), yields
div.formula: Vi1 + Vi2 ≤ -e T x K e e x -K i -i e T qi e qi -β i ||e qi || -κ i ||U i φi || + ėx + K e e x + α fi T ( fi + K fi Λ fi ) + e T qi W T Fi S Fi (z i ) + e T qi ε Fi + β fi Λ T fi fi -e T x β fi Λ Fi(50)
div.p: Then, let us consider the convergence of the FLS weight errors. Taking the derivative of the V i3 in (42), we have
div.formula: Vi3 = tr W T i Γ -1 i Ẇi = -e T qi W T Fi S Fi (z i ) -tr γ i W T i L T i V i ||V i || = -e T qi W T Fi S Fi (z i ) -γ i ||L i || 2 ||V i || || Wi || 2 -γ i C i(51)
div.p: where
div.formula: C i = tr( W T i L T i χ i /||V i ||
div.p: ) is a bounded term. Combining Vi1 , Vi2 and Vi3 , and according to the definition of V i in (39), we can obtain the time derivation of V i as below
div.formula: Vi = Vi1 + Vi2 + Vi3 ≤ -e T x K e e x -K i -i e T qi e qi -β i ||e qi || -κ i ||U i φi || + ėx + K e e x + α fi T ( fi + K fi Λ fi ) + e T qi W T Fi S Fi (z i ) + e T qi ε Fi + β fi Λ T fi fi -e T x β fi Λ Fi -e T qi W T Fi S Fi (z i ) -γ i ||L i || 2 ||V i || || Wi || 2 -γ i C i (52)
div.p: Let us consider the following inequalities,
div.formula: e T qi ε Fi ≤ 1 2 e T qi e qi + 1 2 ε T Fi ε Fi ,(53)
-e T x β fi Λ Fi ≤ β fi 2 e T x e x + β fi 2 Λ T Fi Λ Fi (54)
div.p: Substituting ( 53) into (52), we have
div.formula: Vi ≤ -e T x (K e - β fi 2 )e x -(K i -i - 1 2 )e T qi e qi -β i ||e qi || -κ i ||U i φi || + ėx + K e e x + α fi T ( fi + K fi Λ fi ) -γ i C i + 1 2 ε T Fi ε Fi + β fi Λ T fi fi + β fi 2 Λ T fi Λ fi -γ i ||L i || 2 ||V i || || Wi || 2(55)
div.p: Let α fi = -β fi Λ fi , and
div.formula: K f1 = K f2 = K f , β f1 = β f2 = β f
div.p: with K f and β f being a positive constants. Then, considering the property of internal forces errors f1 + f2 = 0, Λ 1 +Λ 2 = 0, and taking the Lyapunov function
div.formula: V = V 1 +V 2 = 2 i=1 (V i1 + V i2 + V i3 ), we have V = 2 i=1 Vi1 + Vi2 + Vi3 ≤ -e T x (2K e -β f )e x - 2 i=1 (K i -i - 1 2 )e T qi e qi + 2 i=1 -κ i ||U i φi || -β i ||e qi || + β fi Λ T fi fi + 2 i=1 -β fi Λ T fi fi -β fi Λ T fi K f Λ fi + β fi 2 Λ T fi Λ fi - 2 i=1 γ i ||L i || 2 ||V i || || Wi || 2 + γ i C i - 1 2 ε T Fi ε Fi ≤ -e T x (2K e -β fi )e x - 2 i=1 (K i -i -1
div.p: 2 )e T qi e qi
div.formula: + 2 i=1 -β fi Λ T fi (K f - 1 2 )Λ fi - 2 i=1 γ i ||L i || 2 ||V i || || Wi || 2 - 1 2 ε T Fi ε Fi + γ i C i(56)
div.p: If the gains K i and K e are selected to satisfy 56) and the definition of V in ( 39), ( 40), ( 41) and ( 42), we can derive that
div.formula: K i ≥ i + 1 2 and K e ≥ 1 2 β f , γ i is chosen to be γ i ≥ ||(L -1 i ) T Γ -1 i ω i ||, then, from (
V ≤ -ηV + µ (57
div.p: where
div.formula: η = min[λ max 2K e -β fi , λ max Ki-i -I Hi , γ i ||Li|| 2 ||Vi|| , β fi (K f -1 2 )], µ = 1 2 2 i=1 ε T Fi ε Fi + γ i C i , i = 1, 2.
div.p: According to the results in [36], we can derive that the tracking errors and estimation errors could converge to a small neighborhood near zero. This completes the proof.

Theorem 2 shows that the tracking error qi could converge to a small neighborhood of zero. For the estimated parameters Ŵi , however, they may not converge to their optimal values since the PE condition of FLS is not easy to satisfy. According to SLA in (17), the FLS in ( 23) and ( 31) can be expressed using localized Gaussian fuzzy basis functions as
div.formula:      F ijξ (z i ) = W T F ijξ P F ijξ + ε F ijξ Ξ ijξ (z ci ) = W T Ξ ijξ P Ξ ijξ + ε Ξ ijξ Ψ ijξ (z di ) = W T Ψ ijξ P Ψ ijξ + ε Ψ ijξ(58)
div.p: where P (•) ijξ and W (•) ijξ are the subvectors of P (•) and W (•) , whose centers are close to the reference trajectory ϕ iξ = {z iξ , z ciξ , z diξ }. Then (34) can be rewritten as
div.formula: τ ij = W T ijξ P ijξ (Z i ) + ε ijξ , where W ijξ = [W T F ijξ , W T Ξ ijξ , W T Ψ ijξ ] T , P ijξ (Z i ) = [P T F ijf ξ , (P T Ξij ξ -P T Ξ ijf ξ )/2, P T Ψ ijf ξ ] T .
div.p: Since the elements in P (•) ijξ are activated, we can obtain that the regerossers P Fij ξ , P Ξij ξ , P Ψij ξ and P ijξ satisfy the PE condition. For the subvector of FLS weight Ŵijξ , its adaptation law can be designed as
div.formula: Ẇijξ = -Γ ijξ (P F ijξ e T qij + γ i L T ijξ V ijξ ||V ijξ || ) (59
div.p: where P F ijξ , V ijξ and L ijξ are elements of the 'subvertor' version of P Fi , V i and L i . Similar to ( 35) and ( 36), we have
div.formula: L ijξ (t) = t 0 e -δi(t-r) P ijξ (Z i (r))P T ijξ (Z i (r))dr Q ijξ (t) = t 0 e -δi(t-r) P T ijξ (Z i (r))τ ij dr V ijξ (t) = L ijξ Wijξ + χ ijξ (60
div.p: where χ ijξ = -t 0 exp -δ i (t -r) P ijξ (Z i (r))ε ijξ (r)dr. Theorem 3: Consider the dual-arm robot system in (12) and provide the auxiliary controllers qdi in (20). Then, for any recurrent trajectory ϕ ξ (Z i ) starting from the initial condition Z i (0) ∈ Ω 0 (where Ω 0 is a properly chosen compact set), the adaptive control input τ i developed in (24) with the parameter adaptation law in (28) and the FLS weight adaptation law in (59) can guarantee that, (i) the tracking error e x exponentially converges to a small residual set around zero in finite time. (ii) the estimation error φ1 , φ2 , could converge to a small neighbourhood around zero in finite time. (iii) the estimated parameters Ŵi converge to small neighborhoods of their optimal values in finite time.
Proof: Let us consider the following Lyapunov function for the robotic arm i,
div.formula: L i = V i1 + V i2 + V i3ξ(61)
div.p: where V i1 and V i2 are as defined in ( 40) and ( 41) in the proof of Theorem 2, and
div.formula: V i3 ξ = 1 2 Ni j=1 V T ijξ (L -1 ijξ ) T Γ -1 ijξ L -1 ijξ V ijξ(62)
div.p: where Γ iξ is the 'subvertor' version of Γ i . Then considering the L -1 ijξ V ijξ in V i3ξ , the derivation with respect to time gives
div.formula: ∂L -1 ijξ V ijξ ∂t = Ẇijξ -L -1 ijξ Lijξ L -1 ijξ χ ijξ + L -1 ijξ χijξ(63)
div.p: Since P ijξ (Z i ) is PE and Z i is bounded, we can obtain that L -1 ijξ and L-1 ijξ are bounded, then L -1 ijξ is also bounded.
Then, taking the derivative of V i3ξ with respect to time and substituting (63) in it, we have
div.formula: Vi3ξ = Ni j=1 V T ijξ L -1 ijξ Γ -1 ijξ ( Ẇijξ + ω ij )(64)
div.p: where
div.formula: ω ij = -L -1 ijξ Lijξ L -1 ijξ χ ijξ + L -1
div.p: ijξ χijξ . Then, substituting the updating law (59) into (64), and considering V ijξ = L ijξ Wijξ + χ ijξ , we have
div.formula: Vi3ξ = Ni j=1 V T ijξ (L -1 ijξ ) T -P T F ijξ e qij -γ i L T ijξ V ijξ ||V ijξ || + Γ -1 ijξ ω ij ≤ Ni j=1 -V T ijξ (L -1 ijξ ) T P F ijξ e qij + V T ijξ L -1 ijξ T Γ -1 ijξ ω ij + Ni j=1 -γ i V T ijξ (L -1 ijξ ) T L ijξ V ijξ ||V ijξ || ≤ Ni j=1 -W T ijξ P F ijξ e qij + ρ ij ||e qij || - Ni j=1 (γ i -||(L -1 ijξ ) T Γ -1 ijξ ω ij ||)||V ijξ ||(65)
div.p: where ρ ij is a positive parameter defined by
div.formula: ρ ij = ||χ T ijξ (L -1 ijξ ) T P T F ijξ (z i )||.
div.p: According to the definition of χ ijξ , it can be proved that χ ijξ and χijξ are all bounded in terms of the boundness of P ijξ (Z i ) and ε ij , which have been established in Theorem 2. L -1 ijξ is also bounded according to the satisfaction of PPE condition of P ijξ (Z i ). Therefore, we can derive that ρ ij and ω ij are bounded, hence the term ||(L -1 ijξ ) T Γ -1 ijξ ω ij || is also bounded.
Combining Vi1 , Vi2 and Vi3ξ , we can obtain the time derivation of the Lyapunov function
div.formula: L = L 1 + L 2 as below L = 2 i=1 Vi1 + Vi2 + Vi3ξ ≤ -e T x (2K e -β fi )e x - 2 i=1 (K i -i - 1 2 )e T qi e qi + 2 i=1 -κ i ||U i φi || - 2 i=1 (β i -ρ i )||e qi || + 2 i=1 -β fi Λ T fi K f Λ fi + β fi 2 Λ T fi Λ fi + 1 2 ε T Fi ε Fi - 2 i=1 Ni j=1 (γ i -||(L -1 ijξ ) T Γ -1 ijξ ω ij ||)||V ijξ || ≤ 2 i=1 -κ i ||U i φi || - 2 i=1 (β i -ρ i )||e qi || + 2 i=1 - Ni j=1 (γ i -||L -1T ijξ Γ -1 ijξ ω ij ||)||V ijξ || + 1 2 ε T Fi ε Fi ≤ -η 1 √ L + µ 1(66)
div.p: where
div.formula: ρ i = max(ρ i1 , ρ i2 , • • • , ρ iNi ), γ i is chosen to be γ i ≥ ||L -1T ijξ Γ -1 ijξ ω ij ||, β i is chosen to be β i ≥ ρ i , η 1 = √ 2 min λ max γi-||L -1T iξ Γ -1 iξ ωi|| λmin(Γ -1 iξ ) , (β i - ρ i )/ λ min H i , κ i ||U i || √ λ i , µ 1 = 1 2 2 i=1 ε T Fi ε Fi , i = 1, 2.
div.p: Following the results in [44] and according to (66), the tracking errors and the parameter estimation errors could converge to a small neighbourhood near zero in finite time. This completes the proof.

Remark 4: Note that for parameters estimation, the PE (or partial PE) condition should be fulfilled to guarantee the convergence of the estimation errors. Also, in practical robot control implementations, some unknown factors such as friction, actuator nonlinearities, non-rigid grasping and external disturbances may exist. These factors could affect the parameters estimation performance and may degrade the control performance. Further investigation together with experimental studies will be made in our future work.

div.head: IV. SIMULATION STUDY
div.p: To illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme, simulation studies are carried out based on a model of a dual-arm robot with 3 joints for each arm, and in the scenario that a common object is firmly held in between the arms. The robot dynamic model for each arm is described as follows [45]:
div.formula: H i (q i )q i + D i (q i , qi ) qi + G i (q i ) = τ i + J T
div.p: ei (q i )F ei where the manipulator inertial matrix H i (q i ) and Coriolis matrix D(q i qi ) are described as
And s j = sin(q ij ), c j = cos(q ij ), s j1j2 = sin(q ij1 + q ij2 ), c j1j2 = cos(q ij1 + q ij2 ), s 123 = sin(q i1 + q i2 + q i2 ), c 123 = cos(q i1 + q i2 + q i2 ),
The motion dynamic of the object is described as
div.formula: H o ẍ + D o ẋ + G o (x) = F o (67
div.p: where For the fuzzy logic system, Gaussian membership functions are selected for each input dimension. The Gaussian membership functions are continuously differentiable and have the advantage for the theoretical analysis of FLS. We choose parameter -3, -2, -1, 0.5, 1.5, 1, 2 for the central points and π for the standard deviations for the FLS. The initial FLS weights are chosen to be Ŵ1 (0) = 0, Ŵ2 (0) = 0, which will be updated with the FT estimated law (59). The adaptation gains are chosen to be
And the control gains are selected to be positive definite matrix as K e = diag{5, 5, 3}, and K i = diag{20, 10, 9}.

We employ the proposed controller (24) into the dual-arm robot system to achieve the control goal without using a priori knowledge of both the kinematics and dynamics of the robot. The simulation results are performed in Figs. 3-17. An overlook of the tracking performance is shown in Fig. 3, where the grasped object is controlled to follow the periodic tracking trajectories in the phase plane. dashed line '-') and all tracking errors converge to zeros, even in the presence of kinematic and dynamic uncertainties.

To verify the superiority of the proposed control method, comparison studies have been further carried out based on a model based controller [6] and a conventional PD controller. The comparative results are depicted in Figs. 789. From the figures, we can find that the proposed controller (24) obtained the best control performance and tracking errors are much smaller than the other two methods.

The parameters estimation performance is shown in Figs. 10-11. From the figures, we can observe that the estimated kinematic parameters of both arm converge to their real values (blue dash line '-') in a short period of time (less than a periodic). Additionally, the profile of the auxiliary term P 1 , P 2 and the minimum eigenvalue of the auxiliary matrix U 1 , U 2 are also depicted in Fig. 12 and Fig. 13, respectively. It is shown that both σ 1 = λ min (U 1 ) and σ 2 = λ min (U 2 ) are great than zero. This implies that the PE condition is satisfied during the estimation, which has been further verified in Fig. 12, where both P 1 and P 2 (which contain the information of estimation errors) have approached to zero. Therefore the validity of the kinematics identification is demonstrated. In comparison to the work in [12], our proposed method ensures not only the convergence of the tracking errors, but also the finite-time convergence of the estimated parameters.

Simulation results of the proposed fuzzy logic control are depicted in Figs. 14151617. The weights of the fuzzy logic system are shown in Fig. 14 and Fig. 15. From the figures, we can see that the weights of the fuzzy logic systems of both arms are converged with a fast rate. It should also be emphasized that not all of the FLS weights have converged to relatively larger value, and a number of weights only converge to the small Estimation performance of the kinematic parameters l 21 , l 22 , l 23 and lo neighborhood around zero. This is consistent with the partial PE condition and only part of the fuzzy weights are activated and updated by the adaptive law, while for the Gaussian membership functions, whose centers are far away from the FLS inputs, the corresponding FLS weights are not activated and hence will remain in their initial conditions. A comparative study of the FLS weights estimation using gradient descent adaptation is shown in Figs. 16-17. It can be observed that some weights diverge in the estimation and not all the weights are converged to their optimal values.

The simulation results have illustrated that our proposed controller can successfully track the desired trajectory in the presence of uncertain kinematics and dynamics with the guarantee of FT convergence of the estimated weights.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we have developed an adaptive fuzzy control scheme for the coordinated robot arms in the presence of system uncertainties. To guarantee the estimated parameters converge to the optimal values, the partial PE property of fuzzy basis function has been investigated. An FCPA technique is developed for the estimation of both the unknown kinematics parameters and FLS weights. We have shown that, under the partial PE condition, the estimated parameters are able to converge to a small neighborhood of their actual values in a finitesuch that they could be re-used next time with improved computational efficiency and control performance. Extensive simulation studies have been carried out to illustrate that the manipulated object is able to track well a desired trajectory in the presence of uncertain kinematics and dynamics.

div.head: VI. APPENDIX
div.p: Before proceeding to prove Theorem 1, let us introduce some useful definitions and lemmas as below.
Definition 2: [39] A uniformly bounded piecewise continuous vector function P ∈ R m is said to be PE if there where ξ l = [ξ l1 , ξ l2 , • • • , ξ lN ] T . And (70) can be rewritten as
div.formula: p l (Z) = ϕ l (Z) ϕ l + ϕ 2 + • • • + ϕ L(71)
div.p: In comparison to the equations ( 68) and (71), if ρ and ς are chosen to been the same, we can deduce that ϕ l is functional equivalent to a RBF. Then, according to Lemma 2, for the RBF ϕ = [ϕ 1 , ϕ 2 , • • • , ϕ L ] T , there exist an arbitrary selected constant vector c ∈ R L , and positive constants α 1 , α 2 , such that

The ϕ l is bounded with the boundedness of Z according to (71). And from (72) we can also easily obtain that there exist a ϕ l (Z(t)) among ϕ 1 , • • • , ϕ L , such that ϕ l (Z(t)) > 0 in the time interval [t 0 , t 0 + T 0 ]. Let ϕ u = ϕ 1 + • • • + ϕ L , then we have φu ≤ ϕ u ≤ ϕ u with φu and ϕ u are the upper and lower bound of ϕ u , which are positive constants, respectively.

Then, combining (71), (72) and the definition of P ξ , we have From above analysis and Definition 2, we can conclude that for any periodic trajectory Z(t) the corresponding regressor subvector of FLS P ξ (Z(t)) is persistently exciting. This completes the proof.

div.p: This work was partially supported by National Nature Science Foundation (NSFC) under Grant 61473120, 61573174, 61633016 and 61811530281, Science and Technology Planning Project of Guangzhou 201607010006, State Key Laboratory of Robotics and System (HIT) Grant SKLRS-2017-KF-13, the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities 2017ZD057, the Research Fund for Young Top-Notch Talent of National Ten Thousand Talent Program, the Beijing Municipal Natural Science Foundation under Grant 4162066, and the Major Science and Technology Project of Beijing under Grant Z181100003118006.

Chenguang Yang (M'10-SM'16) received the B.Eng. degree in measurement and control from Northwestern Polytechnical University

monogr.title: Yang was a recipient of the Best Paper Award in the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON ROBOTICS and a number of international conferences. Yiming Jiang received the B.S. degree in automation from the Hunan University
